facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 798 of 1963 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated 19th August 1960 of Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 871 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 798 of 1963. Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and Order dated the 19th August, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 871 of 1958.

facts.text: The disputed property consisted of 16 acres and 27 cents of land in Sokkanur village of Coimbatore district.

anchor.surface_text: The disputed property companysisted of 16 acres and 27 cents of land in Sokkanur village of Coimbatore district of which half share belonged to Palani Moopan and the other half to his daughter Palani Mooppachi.

facts.text: Half share of the property belonged to Palani Moopan and the other half to his daughter Palani Mooppachi.

anchor.surface_text: of which half share belonged to Palani Moopan and the other half to his daughter Palani Mooppachi. Palani Moopan executed the document-Ex. B-1 with regard to his share of the property in favour of the 1st defendant for a companysideration of Rs. 4,000/on May 28, 1946.

facts.text: Palani Moopan executed document Ex. B-1 regarding his share to 1st defendant for Rs. 4,000 on May 28, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Palani Moopan executed the document-Ex. B-1 with regard to his share of the property in favour of the 1st defendant for a companysideration of Rs. 4,000/on May 28, 1946. Out of the companysideration, a sum of Rs. 2,000/was reserved with the vendee to pay off an earlier mortgage and the balance of Rs. 2,000/- was paid to the vendor in cash.

facts.text: Out of Rs. 4,000 consideration, Rs. 2,000 reserved with vendee to pay off earlier mortgage, balance Rs. 2,000 paid in cash to vendor.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the companysideration, a sum of Rs. 2,000/was reserved with the vendee to pay off an earlier mortgage and the balance of Rs. 2,000/- was paid to the vendor in cash. The first defendant discharged the earlier mortgage in accordance with the directions in Ex. B-1.

facts.text: First defendant discharged the earlier mortgage as per directions in Ex. B-1.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant discharged the earlier mortgage in accordance with the directions in Ex. B-1. The document, B-1 was in the form of a sale deed but it companytained a stipulation that the 1st defendant should reconvey the property to Palani Moopan on his repaying the amount of Rs. 4,000/- after 5 years and before the end of the 7th year.

facts.text: Ex. B-1 contained stipulation that 1st defendant reconvey property to Palani Moopan on repayment of Rs. 4,000 after 5 years and before end of 7th year.

anchor.surface_text: The document, B-1 was in the form of a sale deed but it companytained a stipulation that the 1st defendant should reconvey the property to Palani Moopan on his repaying the amount of Rs. 4,000/- after 5 years and before the end of the 7th year. After the death of Palani Moopan his sons executed an assignment deed in favour of the plaintiff, Ex. A-1 dated August 10, 1950 for a sum of Rs. 1,600/-.

facts.text: After death of Palani Moopan, his sons executed assignment deed Ex. A-1 in favour of plaintiff dated August 10, 1950 for Rs. 1,600.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Palani Moopan his sons executed an assignment deed in favour of the plaintiff, Ex. A-1 dated August 10, 1950 for a sum of Rs. 1,600/-. On the basis of Ex. A-1 the plaintiff has brought the present suit for redemption of the disputed property.

facts.text: Plaintiff brought suit for redemption of the disputed property on basis of Ex. A-1.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of Ex. A-1 the plaintiff has brought the present suit for redemption of the disputed property. The case of the plaintiff was that Ex. B-1 must be deemed in law to be a mortgage by companyditional sale and that he was entitled to redeem as the assignee of the equity of redemption.

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed Ex. B-1 is mortgage by conditional sale and entitled to redeem as assignee of equity of redemption.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the plaintiff was that Ex. B-1 must be deemed in law to be a mortgage by companyditional sale and that he was entitled to redeem as the assignee of the equity of redemption. The plaintiff further claimed that being an agriculturist, he was entitled to the benefits of Madras Act TV of 1938 as amended.

facts.text: Plaintiff alternatively claimed if Ex. B-1 outright sale with condition to repurchase, 1st defendant bound to reconvey on payment of Rs. 4,000.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff pleaded alternatively that if Sup.Cl/66 12. Ex. B-1 was held to be an out right sale with a companydition to repurchase, the first defendant was bound to reconvey the property to him on payment of the amount of Rs. 4,000/- .

facts.text: Plaintiff alleged he tendered the amount to first defendant several times but latter refused.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff alleged that he tendered the amount to the first defendant several times but the latter refused to accept the same. The suit was companytested by the 1st defendant who denied that Ex. B-1 was a mortgage by companyditional sale.

facts.text: 1st defendant denied Ex. B-1 was mortgage by conditional sale; claimed outright sale with covenant to repurchase, no tender within stipulated time, suit barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by the 1st defendant who denied that Ex. B-1 was a mortgage by companyditional sale. It was alleged that Ex. B-1 was an out right sale with a companyenant to repurchase and as numbertender was made by the plaintiff within the time stipulated in the document, the suit was barred by time.

facts.text: Trial court held Ex. B-1 mortgage by conditional sale, granted preliminary decree for redemption under O. 34 r. 7 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these rival companytentions the trial companyrt held that Ex. B-1 was a mortgage by companyditional sale and accordingly granted a preliminary decree to the plaintiff for redemption under O. 34. r. 7 of the Civil Procedure Code.

facts.text: First defendant appealed to Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant took the matter in appeal to the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore but the appeal was dismissed. The 1st defendant preferred second appeal in the Madras High Court which set aside the decrees of the lower Courts and ordered that the suit should be dismissed, holding that the transaction was an out right sale and number a mortgage by companyditional sale.

facts.text: Madras High Court in second appeal set aside lower court decrees, held transaction outright sale not mortgage, no proof of tender within period, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st defendant preferred second appeal in the Madras High Court which set aside the decrees of the lower Courts and ordered that the suit should be dismissed, holding that the transaction was an out right sale and number a mortgage by companyditional sale. As regards the alternative plea based on the companyenant for reconveyance, the High Court companysidered that there was numberproof that the plaintiff had tendered the amount within the period stipulated in the document.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Ex. B-1 was mortgage by conditional sale, reversed High Court, restored Subordinate Judge decree granting preliminary decree for redemption.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the language of the document, Ex. B-1 and examining it in the light of these circumstances we are of the opinion that the transaction under Ex. B-1 was mortgage by companyditional sale and the view taken by the High Court with regard to the legal effect of the transaction must be reversed.

facts.text: There was an earlier usufructuary mortgage executed on 7th September 1944 for Rs. 4,000 by Palani Moopan and Palani Mooppachi jointly.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 58 c  of the Transfer of Property Act a mortgage by conditional sale is defined as follows 58.  c  Where the mortgagor ostensibly sells the mortgaged property- on condition that on default of payment of the mortgaged-money on a certain date the sale shall become absolute, or on condition that on such payment being made the sale shall become void, or on condition that on such payment being made the buyer shall transfer the property to the seller, the transaction is called a mortgage by conditional sale and the mortgagee a mortgagee by conditional sale Provided that nosuch transaction shall be deemed to be a mortgage, unless the condition is embodied in the document which effects or purports to effect the sale.

concepts.interpretation: Condition must be embodied in the sale document; mere embodiment insufficient without intention to create mortgage relation; intention determined from deed language and surrounding circumstances.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: . The proviso to this clause was added by Act 20 of 1929. Prior to the amendment there was a companyflict of decisions on the question whether the com

concepts.unlisted_description: Definition of mortgage by conditional sale

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to this clause was added by Act 20 of 1929. Prior to the amendment there was a conflict of decisions on the question whether the condition contained in a separate deed could be taken into account in ascertaining whether a mortgage was intended by the principal deed.

concepts.interpretation: Amended proviso to require condition embodied in the sale document itself to deem transaction a mortgage.

concepts.unlisted_label: Test to distinguish mortgage by conditional sale from sale with condition to reconvey
concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor test based on intention, circumstances like price, possession indicators, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of a mortgage by conditional sale postulates the creation by the transfer of a relation of mortgagor and mortgagee, the price being charged on the property conveyed. In a sale coupled with an agreement to reconvey there is no relation of debtor and creditor nor is the price charged upon the property conveyed, but the sale is subject to an obligation to retransfer the property within the period specified.

concepts.interpretation: Presence of debtor-creditor relation and property as security distinguishes mortgage from conditional sale.

holdings.text: The transaction under Ex. B-1 was a mortgage by conditional sale and the view taken by the High Court with regard to the legal effect of the transaction must be reversed.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the language of the document, Ex. B-1 and examining it in the light of these circumstances we are of the opinion that the transaction under Ex. B-1 was mortgage by conditional sale and the view taken by the High Court with regard to the legal effect of the transaction must be reversed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of deed and surrounding circumstances (embodied condition, inadequate consideration, patta retention, kist payment by seller, same reconveyance amount) indicate intention to create security/debtor-creditor relation per s.58(c) TPA.

holdings.text: The criticism of learned Counsel for the appellant is justified and we must proceed on the basis that the valuation of the property was Rs. 8,000/-

The criticism of learned Counsel for the appellant is justified and we must proceed on the basis that the valuation of the property was Rs. 8,000/-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuation finding by lower courts is factual, High Court erred in second appeal by re-assessing it.

holdings.text: The plaintiff is entitled to a preliminary decree for redemption under O. 34 r. 7 Civil Procedure Code, for taking accounts and for declaration of the amounts due to the 1st defendant under Ex. B-1.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that the plaintiff is entitled to a preliminary decree for redemption under 0. 34. r. 7, Civil Procedure Code, for taking accounts and for declaration of the amounts due to the 1st defendant under Ex. B-1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: As assignee of equity of redemption in valid mortgage by conditional sale, plaintiff entitled to redemption decree.

holdings.text: We set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore granting the plaintiff a preliminary decree for redemption of the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore granting the plaintiff a preliminary decree for redemption of the mortgage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in classifying transaction as sale; lower court's mortgage finding correct.

holdings.text: A period of six months is granted for payment of the amount under the preliminary decree.

outcome.relief_summary: Judgment and decree of the High Court set aside; judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore restored, granting plaintiff preliminary decree for redemption of the mortgage under O. 34 r. 7 CPC.
directions: A period of six months is granted for payment of the amount under the preliminary decree.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the language of the document, Ex. B-1 and examining it in the light of these circumstances we are of the opinion that the transaction under Ex. B-1 was mortgage by conditional sale and the view taken by the High Court with regard to the legal effect of the transaction must be reversed.

For these reasons we set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and. restore the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore granting the plaintiff a preliminary decree for redemption of the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has dealt with this question and reached the finding that the value of the property was Rs. 5,500/-, but it is submitted by Mr. Ganapathi lyer on behalf of the appellant that the question of valuation was one of fact and the High Court was not entitled to go into the question in the second appeal. The criticism of learned Counsel for the appellant is justified and we must proceed on the basis that the valuation of the property was Rs. 8,000/-

For these reasons we set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and. restore the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore granting the plaintiff a preliminary decree for redemption of the mortgage.

For these reasons we set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and. restore the judgment and decree of the Subordinate Judge of Coimbatore granting the plaintiff a preliminary decree for redemption of the mortgage.
